{{Infobox Civil Conflict | conflict = 2010â2011 Algerian protests | partof = the [[Arab Spring]] | image = [[File:Manifestation Algiers RCD - 01222011.jpg|300px]] | caption = Demonstration organised by RCD in Algiers | date = {{Start date|2010|12|28}} â ''ongoing'' | place = {{flag|Algeria}} | causes = <nowiki></nowiki> * [[Inflation]] * [[salaries|Low Salaries]] * [[Unemployment]] * [[Regressive tax|Regressive Taxes]] | status = Ongoing | goals = <nowiki></nowiki> * [[Regime change|Regime Change]] * [[Human Rights]] * [[Democracy]] | result = <!-- Use once the protests are over --> | methods = <nowiki></nowiki> * [[Civil resistance]] * [[Demonstration (people)|Demonstrations]] | concessions = | injuries = 420+<ref name="Protests Inspired by Tunisia Leave Three Dead"/> | fatalities = 8<ref name="Protests Inspired by Tunisia Leave Three Dead">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-25/egyptian-policeman-two-people-killed-in-cairo-protest-inspired-by-tunisia.html|title=Egyptian Protests Inspired by Tunisia Leave Three Dead|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=26 January 2010 |accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="aljaz_alg_12Feb"/>}}
The '''2010â2011 Algerian protests''' are a continuing series of protests taking place throughout [[Algeria]] from 28 December 2010 onwards, part of similar [[Arab Spring|protests across the Middle East and North Africa]]. Causes cited by the protestors include [[unemployment]], the lack of housing, food-price [[inflation]], [[Political corruption|corruption]], restrictions on [[freedom of speech]] and poor [[living conditions]]. While localised protests were already commonplace over previous years, extending into December 2010, an unprecedented wave of simultaneous protests and riots, sparked by sudden rises in staple food prices, erupted all over the country starting in January 2011. These were quelled by government measures to lower food prices, but were followed by a wave of [[self-immolation]]s, most of them in front of government buildings. Opposition parties, unions, and human rights organisations then began to hold weekly demonstrations, despite these being illegal without government permission under the ongoing [[state of emergency]]; the government suppressed these demonstrations as far as possible, but in late February yielded to pressure and lifted the state of emergency. Meanwhile, protests by unemployed youth, typically citing unemployment, ''hogra'' (oppression), and infrastructure problems, resumed, occurring almost daily in towns scattered all over the country.
==Background== After the riots of 1988, the Algerian government had moved towards democracy, holding free elections. However, when the [[Islamic Salvation Front]] (FIS) won the first free [[Algerian legislative election, 1991|parliamentary election]] in 1991, the military staged a coup d'Ã©tat, voided the election results, declared a state of emergency which remained in force until 2011,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/algeria-uses-emergency-law-to-fight-islamic-group-1471880.html |title=Algeria uses emergency law to fight Islamic group |publisher=The Independent |date=9 February 1993 |accessdate=13 February 2011 |location=London |first=Charles |last=Richards}}</ref> and arrested the FIS leadership. This led to the founding of the [[Armed Islamic Group of Algeria|Armed Islamic Groups]] (GIA) and the ten-year [[Algerian Civil War]], in which an estimated 150,000 people were killed.
With the unchallenged [[Algerian presidential election, 1999|election]] of [[Abdelaziz Bouteflika]] as president in 1999, civilian government was nominally restored. Violence died down as both guerrillas and soldiers were given impunity for their previous acts under the controversial [[Charter for Peace and National Reconciliation]]. Towards the end of his second term, Bouteflika amended the constitution to allow himself to run for a third term in 2009; to no one's surprise, he won the ensuing [[Algerian presidential election, 2009|election]], with, according to the opposition and the US Embassy, a very low turnout.
Seventy percent of Algeria's population is less than 30 years old. Consequent high levels of youth unemployment, coupled with corruption and widespread poverty, are seen as reasons for dissatisfaction.<ref name="afrik">{{cite web|author=Djamel Belayachi |url=http://www.afrik-news.com/article18940.html |title=Algeria protests take place amid 30,000 police deployment - Afrik-news.com : Africa news, Maghreb news - The african daily newspaper |publisher=Afrik-news.com |date=|accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
The leader of the [[Rally for Culture and Democracy]], [[SaÃ¯d Sadi]], claimed that during 2010, there were "9,700 riots and unrests" in Algeria.<ref name="army_should_quit">{{cite news | first=Lamine | last=Chikhi | pages= | language =| title=Algeria army should quit politics: opposition | date=21 January 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE70K02X20110121?sp=true |accessdate=22 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vuh49u62 |archivedate=21 January 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Some protests were about issues such as education and health care, as well as rampant corruption.<ref>{{cite news|first=Mahmoud |last=Belhimer |url=http://carnegieendowment.org/arb/?fa=show&article=40363 |title=Political Crises but Few Alternatives in Algeria |work=Arab Reform Bulletin |publisher=Carnegie Endowment for International Peace |date=17 March 2010 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
Prior to the outbreak of protests, in February 2008, [[United States]] Ambassador [[Robert Stephen Ford|Robert Ford]] in [[WikiLeaks cables|leaked]] [[diplomatic cables]] called Algeria "an unhappy country", stating "There is much discussion among political circles about the [[Constitution of Algeria|constitution]], the third term and the succession issue, but precious little discussion about how to address long-standing political alienation and social discontent throughout the country."<ref name="08ALGIERS198">{{cite document| last =Ford| first =Robert | authorlink =| coauthors =| title = Scene setter for A/S Welch visit to Algeria | id={{WikiLeaks cable|08ALGIERS198}} |work =| publisher =[[WikiLeaks]]| date=22 February 2008| url =http://wikileaks.ch/cable/2008/02/08ALGIERS198.html |format =| doi =| accessdate=22 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vumgk7y9 |archivedate=22 January 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> He claimed there were strikes over food "by [[Trade unions in Algeria|different labor groups]] almost weekly" and that "almost daily there are isolated demonstrations with the occasional government office in some distant town attacked."<ref name="08ALGIERS198" /> Ford stated that "voter turnout for the [[Algerian legislative election, 2007|2007 legislative]] and local elections was lower than ever before because Algeria's young people do not see the political system as having any relevance to addressing their problem."<ref name="08ALGIERS198" /> United States diplomats also claimed that the Algerian regime is more corrupt than the international community realises and is also more fragile. The [[diplomatic cable]] also said that Bouteflika may have cancer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://213.251.145.96/cable/2007/12/07ALGIERS1806.html |title=Cable Viewer |publisher=213.251.145.96 |date=|accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
===29 December 2010=== On 29 December 2010, clashes with police were reported in Algiers during protests about the lack of housing. At least 53 people were reported to have been injured and another 29 were arrested.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/2010123012345588575.html |title=Scores hurt in Algeria protests â Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=30 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref>
==National, 3â10 January 2011==
In 2011, prices of basic foodstuffs rose significantly in Algeria,<ref>[http://www.letempsdz.com/content/view/50717/1/ Hausse gÃ©nÃ©ralisÃ©e des prix des produits alimentaires] Le Temps 01/01/2011</ref> in line with global trends but also reflecting newly imposed regulations.<ref>[http://mideast.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2011/01/09/algeria_s_national_protesta Algeria's National Protests] Hugh Roberts, ''[[Foreign Policy]]'' 10/01/2011</ref> [[2010-2011 Tunisian protests|Unprecedented protests in neighbouring Tunisia]] over unemployment were already being reported, contributing to the mood.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011171242359602.html Algeria police on alert after riots] [[Aljazeera]] English 08/01/2011</ref>
[[Image:Renault-BEO-IncendiÃ©.jpg|thumb|upright|The [[Renault]] shop of Triolet near Bab El Oued, burnt in the riots.|alt=Broken shop curtain with people looking inside.]]
Between 3 and 10 January, riots and protests broke out across most Algerian towns, triggered by large increases in the prices of basic foods including oil, sugar, and flour. While localised riots have been a frequent occurrence in Algeria since 2005, this set of riots was the first to spread across most regions of the country simultaneously rather than being confined to a particular area. By 10 January they were limited to a few towns, but continued in those towns.<ref>[http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hLhKLduS1LRRYOBpAaq5kpyJNbuQ?docId=CNG.a7256a3419e3e3b03b8d1b50e17ae892.b61 Unrest eases in Algeria as prices drop] Beatrice Khadige, AFP 10/01/2011</ref> More organised efforts to demonstrate on the 11 January in Algiers were suppressed vigorously by the police.<ref>[http://www.elwatan.com/evenement/quatre-heures-au-commissariat-de-staoueli-11-01-2011-106707_115.php quatre-heures-au-commissariat-de-staoueli] (subscription required) El Watan, 11/01/2011</ref>
Protests against the price increases started on 3 January, with protest in the Ras El Ain quarter of [[Oran]],<ref name="Voix Oranie PDF">''La Voix de l'Oranie'' 05/01/2011, p 2 [http://www.voix-oranie.com/assets/Archives/05-01-2011/journal.pdf PDF]</ref> and in [[Fouka]] and [[Staoueli]] near Algiers.<ref name="Voix Oranie PDF" /> On 4 January they were repeated in Staoueli and spread to other areas near the capital, with impromptu roadblocks at Douaouda in [[Tipasa]].<ref name="Voix Oranie PDF" /> and Kolea<ref>[http://dna-algerie.com/politique/54-dna-en-pointilles/1038-emeutes-a-kolea-des-manifestants-bloquent-lacces-a-la-ville.html emeutes a kolea des manifestants bloquent lacces a la ville] DNA 01/05/2011</ref>
On 5 January, major riots broke out in several areas at once: in the Bab El Oued neighbourhood of the capital, [[Algiers]],<ref>[http://www.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/International/2011/01/05/008-algerie-emeutes-cherte.shtml algerie emeutes cherte] Radio Canada, 05/02/2011</ref> and nearby suburbs, as well as Algeria's second city, [[Oran]], and other towns including [[Djelfa]], [[Boumerdes]], [[Annaba]], and [[Tipaza]].<ref>[http://www.lematindz.net/news/3578-urgent-des-coups-de-feu-a-alger-lembrasement-a-oran.html urgent des coups de feu a alger lembrasement a oran] Le Matin, 05/02/2011</ref> The young men rioting blocked roads, burned tires, and sacked government buildings, protesting the sudden increase in the [[cost of living]],<ref>[http://www.elwatan.com/evenement/protestation-et-panique-au-centre-ville-d-oran-06-01-2011-106020_115.php protestation et panique au centre ville d oran] El Watan, 06/01/2011</ref> the demolition of [[shantytown]]s, and broader issues such as unemployment.<ref>[http://www.lexpressiondz.com/article/2/2011-01-06/84584.html Plusieurs quartiers en proie Ã la protestation] L'Expression, 06/01/2011</ref> They were met by anti-riot forces, who attempted to disperse the crowds. In Bab El Oued, shops and car showrooms were also targeted.<ref name="watan1">Salim Mesbah, [http://www.elwatan.com/une/emeutes-l-embrasement-07-01-2011-106141_108.php Ãmeutes : L'embrasement]{{dead link|date=February 2011}}, El Watan, 7-1-2011 issn 1111-0333</ref> <ref>Le Soir d'AlgÃ©rie issn 1111-0074 [http://www.lesoirdalgerie.com/articles/2011/01/08/article.php?sid=111035&cid=2 Les deux folles nuits dâAlger] 8 janvier 2011</ref> Former [[Islamic Salvation Front]] number two [[Ali Belhadj]] went to Bab El Oued to see the events and encourage the youths; he was arrested later that day, as were many other protesters and rioters.<ref name="Djamel Belayachi">{{cite web |url=http://www.afrik.com/article21672.html |title=Nouvelle vague dâÃ©meutes sur lâAlgÃ©rie |author=Djamel Belayachi |date=7 Jan 2011 |work=Afrik.com|accessdate=8 Jan 2011}}</ref>
Within days the riots spread to twenty-odd ''[[wilayah]]s'', covering almost the whole of the north including the [[Kabylie]] region,<ref>[http://www.elwatan.com/regions/kabylie/bajaia/les-esprits-ne-se-sont-pas-apaises-10-01-2011-106581_143.php les esprits ne se sont pas apaises] El Watan 10/01/2011</ref> as well as some towns in the [[Sahara]], such as [[Ouargla]]<ref>[http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/ouargla-apres-un-calme-precaire-la-matinee-l-emeute-a-repris-08-01-2011-106369_109.php ouargla apres un calme precaire la matinee l emeute a repris] El Watan, 08/01/2011</ref> and [[Bechar]].<ref>[http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1096-emeutes-des-centaines-de-manifestants-en-instance-de-jugement.html emeutes des centaines de manifestants en instance de jugement] DNA, 09/01/2011</ref> Government buildings, particularly town halls, were widely targeted, and shops in some areas were looted or burned;<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011166020620356.html Price protests erupt across Algeria] [[Aljazeera]] English 07/01/2011</ref> some of the looters carried swords.<ref name="Yasmine Ryan">{{cite news | last= Ryan | first= Yasmine | url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011171242359602.html | title= Algeria police on alert after riots | publisher= [[Aljazeera]] | date=08 Jan 2011 | accessdate=}}</ref> Football matches scheduled for the 7th and 8th were cancelled.<ref name="Yasmine Ryan" />
On 8 January, the government agreed to a temporary cut in taxes and duties on [[sugar]] and [[cooking oil]].<ref name="Beatrice Khadige">{{cite news | last= Khadige | first= Beatrice | url= http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hLhKLduS1LRRYOBpAaq5kpyJNbuQ?docId=CNG.a7256a3419e3e3b03b8d1b50e17ae892.b61 | title= Unrest eases in Algeria as prices drop | publisher= AFP | date=10 January 2011 | accessdate=}}</ref> [[Censorship of Facebook|Facebook]] and [[Twitter#Censorship|Twitter]] access were also restricted in some areas.<ref name="Belmadi Censure">{{cite news | last= Belmadi | first= Tayeb | url= http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1106-censure-filtrage-lenteurs-de-connexion-pourquoi-facebook-nest-pas-accessible-en-algerie.html | title= Censure, filtrage, connexion lente : Pourquoi Facebook n'est pas accessible en AlgÃ©rie | publisher= DerniÃ¨res nouvelles d'AlgÃ©rie | language=French | date=10 Jan 2011 | accessdate=}}</ref> The rioting continued, at least up to 10 January in some places, such as the Bachdjarrah neighbourood in Algiers.<ref>[http://www.elwatan.com/une/alger-affrontements-violents-lundi-matin-a-bachdjerrah-10-01-2011-106641_108.php alger affrontements violents lundi matin a bachdjerrah]{{dead link|date=February 2011}} El Watan 10/01/2011</ref> By 11 January, the situation had calmed; an attempt to demonstrate on the 11th in Algiers, organised in advance by the intercommunal committee of Ain Benian and Staoueli, was repressed vigorously by the police.<ref>[http://www.elwatan.com/evenement/quatre-heures-au-commissariat-de-staoueli-11-01-2011-106707_115.php quatre heures au commissariat de staoueli] El Watan, 11/01/2011</ref> In total, three demonstrators died, more than 800 people had been wounded, and at least 1,100 were arrested, many of them minors.<ref>[http://www.elwatan.com/une/1100-manifestants-arretes-10-01-2011-106567_108.php manifestants-arretes]{{dead link|date=February 2011}} El Watan, 10/01/2011</ref>
===Political implications===
While riots on this scale are unprecedented since the [[Algerian legislative election, 1991|1991 election]], their wider political implications are not yet clear. The rioters had no collective ties to any Algerian political party, organisation, or trade union,<ref name="Hugh Roberts FP">{{cite news | url= http://mideast.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2011/01/09/algeria_s_national_protesta | title= Algeria's National 'Protesta' | last= Roberts | first= Hugh | work= [[Foreign Policy]] | date=10 January 2011 | accessdate= }}</ref> and some sources commented that they seemed to have no political slogans.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lexpressiondz.com/article/2/2011-01-10/84729.html |title={{lang|fr|Des protestations sans slogans politiques}} |work=L'Expression |date=10 January 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.elwatan.com/une/les-classes-moyennes-et-la-classe-politique-pour-relayer-les-emeutes-09-01-2011-106403_108.php |title={{lang|fr|les classes moyennes et la classe politique pour relayer les emeutes}} |work=El Watan |date=9 January 2011 }}</ref> Some opposition groups emphasised the riots' political dimension; ex-diplomat and opposition spokesperson [[Mohamed Larbi Zitout]] described them as "a revolt, and probably a revolution, of an oppressed people",<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011187476735721.html |title=Algeria set for crisis talks |work=Aljazeera English |date=8 January 2011 }}</ref> while the [[Socialist Forces Front]] responded to the government's lowering of food prices on 8 January with the slogan "The government cannot buy Algerians' silence".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ffs-dz.com/Le-pouvoir-ne-peut-pas-acheter-le.html |title={{lang|fr|Le pouvoir ne peut pas acheter le silence des algÃ©riens}} |publisher=FFS DÃ©claration du SecrÃ©tariat national |date=8 January 2011 }}</ref> [[Agence France Presse]] (AFP) has linked the January protests with events in Tunisia, stating, "In Tunisia, [[2010â2011 Tunisian protests|similar unrest]] sparked the overthrow of the government of [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali|Zine Al Abidine Ben Ali]], whose 23 years in power ended with his flight to [[Saudi Arabia]] last Friday. Algerian commentators have said that more Tunisia-style protests could break out in Algeria."<ref name="jordantimes">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Algerian opposition says will defy protest ban | date=21 January 2011 | publisher=[[Jordan Times]]/[[Agence France Presse|AFP]] | url=http://www.jordantimes.com/?news=33709 |accessdate=19 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vuaBbMxC |archivedate=21 January 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Despite their scale, the riots were dealt with by the government in much the same way as the localised riots that had already become a routine way of communicating grievances: it sought to avoid creating [[martyr]]s and made a specific concession (in this case, a return to the ''status quo ante'' of allowing un-declared food sales by [[Cevital]]) not seen as threatening the overall system.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.merip.org/mero/mero012011.html |title=Algeriaâs Midwinter Uproar |work=Middle East Report Online |date=20 January 2011 |first=Jack |last=Brown }}</ref>
==Self-immolations (starting 12 January)==
{{main|2011 Algerian self-immolations}}
[[image:Mohsen Bouterfif.jpg|thumb|upright|Mohsen Bouterfif in the hospital showing the wounds from his self-immolation]] As the widely reported protests sparked off by [[Mohamed Bouazizi]]'s self-immolation in Tunisia began to have a clear impact on the Tunisian government, a wave of [[self-immolation]]s swept Algeria. These individual acts of protest mostly took place in front of a government building following an unsuccessful approach to the authorities. Four self-immolators have died of their burns so far.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ennaharonline.com/en/news/5671.html |title=Algeria: Third death by self-immolation |publisher=Ennahar Online |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Article/ARTJAWEB20110212105526/algerie-pauvrete-tunisie-manifestationquatrieme-deces-par-immolation-en-algerie-a-la-veille-de-la-marche-du-12-fevrier.html |title=Jeune Afrique, 12/01/2011, QuatriÃ¨me dÃ©cÃ¨s par immolation en AlgÃ©rie, Ã la veille de la marche du 12 fÃ©vrier |publisher=Jeune Afrique |date=|accessdate=17 February 2011}}</ref>
It began on 12 January, when 26 year-old Mohamed Aouichia set himself on fire in [[Bordj Menaiel]] in the compound of the ''[[Districts of Algeria|daira]]'' building. He had been sharing a room of 30 square metres with seven other people, including his sister, since 2003; he had repeatedly approached local authorities to get on the social housing list and been rebuffed.<ref name="courrierinternational1">{{cite web|url=http://www.courrierinternational.com/article/2011/01/21/je-brule-donc-je-suis |title=Courrier International, 21/01/2011, ''Je brÃ»le donc je suis'' |publisher=Courrierinternational.com |date=21 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> He has so far survived.
On 13 January, [[Mohsen Bouterfif]], a 37-year-old father of two, set himself on fire. He had gone with about twenty other youths to protest in front of the town hall of [[Boukhadra]] in Tebessa demanding jobs and houses, after the mayor refused to receive them. According to one testimony, the mayor shouted to them: "If you have courage, do like Bouazizi did, set yourself on fire!"<ref> {{cite web|url= http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1210-le-maire-a-mohcin-bouterfif-l-si-tu-as-du-courage-fais-comme-bouazizi-immole-toi-par-le-feu-r.html|title=Le maire Ã Mohcin Bouterfif : " Si tu as du courage, fais comme Bouazizi, immole-toi par le feu "}}</ref> His death was reported on 16 January, and about 100 youths protested his death causing the provincial governor to sack the mayor.<ref name="bouterfif_aljaz">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/20111162363063915.html|title=Algerian dies from self-immolation}}</ref> However, hospital staff the following day claimed he was still alive, though in critical condition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Article/ARTJAWEB20110117084410/algerie-pauvrete-tunisie-mostaganemvague-de-tentatives-de-suicide-par-le-feu-en-algerie.html |title=''Vague de tentatives de suicide par le feu en AlgÃ©rie'' |publisher=Jeune Afrique |date=17 January 2001 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> [[Al Jazeera]] described the suicide as "echoing the [[Mohamed Bouazizi#Confiscation of wares and self-immolation|self-immolation]] that triggered the [[2010â2011 Tunisian protests|protests]] that toppled the leader of neighbouring Tunisia."<ref name="bouterfif_aljaz" /> He finally died on 24 January at a hospital in Annaba.<ref>http://www.elwatan.com/une/deces-du-jeune-qui-s-est-immole-a-tebessa-24-01-2011-108628_108.php DÃ©cÃ¨s du jeune qui s'est immolÃ© Ã Tebessa]{{dead link|date=February 2011}} El Watan, 24/01/2011</ref>
These suicides were followed by dozens more attempted or successful self-immolations across the country, so far without triggering nation-wide demonstrations, most of them after the Tunisian dictator [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] fled his country on 14 January.
==Response of the parties and unions== ===Late January 2011=== [[File:110109 Algeria slashes food prices amid riots 001.jpg|thumb|Protesters]] A number of left-wing opposition parties, including the [[Socialist Forces Front|FFS]], RCD, [[Party of Liberty and Justice|PLJ]], and the Communist [[Democratic and Social Movement (Algeria)|MDS]], as well as the [[Algerian League for Human Rights]] (LADDH) and officially unrecognised unions, such as SATEF and SNAPAP, met on 20 January to discuss responses to the situation. On 21 January, several of them (excluding the FFS<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ffs1963.unblog.fr/2011/01/22/le-ffs-estime-que-la-concertation-doit-sapprofondir-et-eventuellement-selargir-a-lavenir/ |title=''Le FFS estime que la concertation doit sâapprofondir et Ã©ventuellement sâÃ©largir Ã lâavenir'', 22/01/2011 |publisher=Ffs1963.unblog.fr |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1200-le-ffs-de-hocine-ait-ahmed-demande-une-autorisation-pour-un-meeting-a-bab-el-oued-alger.html |title=DNA AlgÃ©rie, 23/01/2011, ''Le FFS de Hocine Ait Ahmed demande une autorisation pour un meeting Ã Bab El Oued (Alger)'' |publisher=Dna-algerie.com |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>) formed the [[Coordination Nationale pour le Changement et la DÃ©mocratie]] (National Coordination for Change and Democracy), seeking systemic change within the country<ref name="afrik"/> and calling (along with [[Rachad]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rachad.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=604&catid=69&Itemid=101 |title=Rachad, ''Appel Ã des manifestations pour les droits et libertÃ©s en AlgÃ©rie'' |publisher=Rachad.org |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>) for nationwide marches, starting 9 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biladi.fr/011168180-marches-prevues-le-9-fevrier-partis-et-syndicats-sagitent |title=Biladi, 21/01/2011, ''AlgÃ©rie : Marches prÃ©vues le 9 fÃ©vrier - Partis et syndicats s'agitent'' |publisher=Biladi.fr |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> The Interior Minister, Ould Kablia, responded that "No march would be authorised by the authorities in Algiers... Marches are forbidden in Algiers."<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/ould-kablia-aucune-marche-ne-sera-autorisee-a-alger-30-01-2011-109447_109.php El Watan | title= Ould Kablia : " aucune marche ne sera autorisÃ©e Ã Alger " | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=30 January 2011 | accessdate=30/01/2011 }}</ref>
Meanwhile, the mainly [[Kabylie|Kabyle]]-based secularist [[Rally for Culture and Democracy|RCD]] party had announced plans for a march for democracy to be held on Saturday 22 January, despite being refused permission by the government<ref name="jordantimes" /> under the state of emergency.<ref name="army_should_quit" /> Prior to the March, RCD leader [[SaÃ¯d Sadi]] linked the planned march to the [[2010â2011 Tunisian protests]], stating, "If the opposition does not mobilise the crowds, we believe that we will have more devastating events than what happened in Tunisia. The anger here is bigger than (it was) in Tunisia."<ref name="army_should_quit" /> He also called for the [[Algerian civil war#Elections cancelled: a guerrilla war begins|1992]] state of emergency to be lifted and for the army to withdraw from politics, stating, "The army should no longer be a decision maker, it has to become a state institution."<ref name="army_should_quit" /> The march attracted about 300 people, and was broken up by the police; 42 people (according to the RCD<ref>{{fr}}{{cite web|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/international/manifestation-interdite-a-alger-42-blesses-selon-l-opposition-22-01-2011-1239009.php |title=Manifestation interdite Ã Alger : 42 blessÃ©s selon l'opposition |publisher=Leparisien.fr |date=22 January 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>) or 19 (according to the Interior Ministry<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1202-premier-cas-de-deces-par-immolation-en-algerie-karim-bendine-35-ans-succombe-a-ses-brulures.html |title=DNA AlgÃ©rie, 23/01/2011, ''Premier cas de dÃ©cÃ¨s par immolation en AlgÃ©rie : Karim Bendine, 35 ans, succombe Ã ses brÃ»lures'' |publisher=Dna-algerie.com |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>) were injured, and 9, including the head of the party's parliamentary group Othman Amazouz, were arrested, to be released later the same day.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011122105819527114.html Aljazeera English, 22/01/2011, ''Algerian democracy rally broken up''], [http://www.elwatan.com/depeches/algerie-fin-d-une-manifestation-d-opposition-a-alger-7-blesses-22-01-2011-108265_167.php El Watan, 22/01/2011, ''AlgÃ©rie: fin d'une manifestation d'opposition Ã Alger, 7 blessÃ©s''], [http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/les-9-personnes-interpellees-a-alger-relachees-22-01-2011-108301_109.php El Watan, 22/01/2011, ''Les 9 personnes interpellÃ©es Ã Alger relÃ¢chÃ©es'']</ref> Some demonstrators waved the [[Tunisia]]n flag, alluding to the protests which had brought down Ben Ali.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12258449 |title=BBC News, 22/01/2011, ''Several injured in pro-democracy march in Algiers'' |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=22 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Would-be demonstrators coming from [[Tizi Ouzou]] were prevented from reaching the scene by the police.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tsa-algerie.com/divers/des-etudiants-de-tizi-ouzou-interceptes-a-bab-ezzouar_13879.html |title=TSA AlgÃ©rie, 21/01/2011, ''Des Ã©tudiants de Tizi Ouzou interceptÃ©s Ã Bab Ezzouar'' |publisher=Tsa-algerie.com |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> On 22 January, 20,000 police officers stopped all protests. In the ensuing clash five people were killed and more than 800 others hurt.<ref name="aljaz_alg_12Feb"/>
On 23 January, the FFS and LADDH jointly issued a demand for the release of the demonstrators arrested in early January, in [[Tizi-Ouzou]] and elsewhere;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/tizi-ouzou-le-ffs-et-la-laddh-exigent-la-liberation-des-manifestants-23-01-2011-108440_109.php |title=El Watan, 23/01/2011, ''Tizi Ouzou : Le FFS et la LADDH exigent la libÃ©ration des manifestants'' |publisher=Elwatan.com |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> students of [[Tizi-Ouzou]] announced plans for a march on 1 February demanding their release and economic development for Kabylie.<ref>{{cite web|author=Accueil |url=http://dna-algerie.com/component/content/article/34-politique/1199-les-etudiants-appellent-a-une-marche-populaire-a-tizi-ouzou-le-1er-fevrier.html |title=DNA AlgÃ©rie, 23/01/2011, ''Les Ã©tudiants appellent Ã une marche populaire Ã Tizi Ouzou le 1er fÃ©vrier'' |publisher=Dna-algerie.com |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
On the 29th of January, the RCD organised a march of over ten thousand people (according to the organisers) in the city of [[Bejaia]], to demand more freedom and democracy.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20110129/wl_africa_afp/algeriapoliticsunrestprotesttunisia_20110129210556 | title= Thousands in Algeria protest march: organisers | publisher= ''AFP'' | date=29 January 2011 | accessdate=29/01/2011 }}</ref>
===Early February 2011=== Protests continued on 3 February. On the same day President Abdelaziz Bouteflika signaled at a meeting with government ministers his intention to lift the 19-year-old state of emergency in the "very near future", in what was seen as an attempt to quell opposition demands. Reportedly, he also urged the cabinet to adopt measures to promote job creation and said Algeria's TV and radio should give airtime to all political parties.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12359750 | title=Algeria state of emergency: Bouteflika 'signals end' | date=3 February 2011 | accessdate=3 February 2011 | publisher=BBC}}</ref> On 4 February, [[Al Jazeera]] reported that demonstrations were planned for 12 February.<ref name="aljaz_febdominos">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Calls for weekend protests in Syria | date=4 February 2011 | publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122171649677912.html |accessdate=8 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wLygnerq |archivedate=8 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
While Bouteflika was said to be working to counter the planned demonstration, on 8 February university students commenced an "indefinite strike" in protest against the "poor quality of teaching."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afrol.com/articles/37264 |title=afrol News - Large student protests in Algeria |publisher=Afrol.com |date=|accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref> On the same day, an indefinite strike was also launched by professional paramedics after a call by the trade union SAP. However, it was reported to have been observed in only 22 of the country's 48 provinces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ennaharonline.com/en/news/5754.html |title=Algeria paramedics strike shortly followed |publisher=Ennahar Online |date=9 February 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
===12 February=== The day after Egyptian President [[Hosni Mubarak]] resigned, the protest gained new currency.<ref name="aljazlive">[[Al Jazeera English]]. Headlines.</ref> The protests were organised by the nascent National Co-ordination for Change and Democracy, an umbrella group of opposition parties, civil society groups and unofficial unions.<ref name="aljaz12feb"/> The police blocked all entry points into Algiers<ref name="nyt_alg_12Feb">{{cite news | first=Adam | last= Nossiter |coauthors= Timothy Williams | pages= | language =| title=Security Forces Halt Protest in Algeria | date=12 February 2011 | publisher=New York Times | url= http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/13/world/africa/13algeria.html?_r=4 |accessdate=12 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wS0Zwdu6 |archivedate=12 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}, {{cite news | first=Adam | last= Nossiter |coauthors= Timothy Williams | pages= | language =| title=Security Forces Halt Protest in Algeria | date=12 February 2011 | publisher=New York Times | url= http://www10.nytimes.com/2011/02/13/world/africa/13algeria.html?_r=5&pagewanted=2 |accessdate=12 February 2011 |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/5wS0cfWPN |archivedate=12 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> and put in a security cordon around [[May First Square]] in central Algiers.<ref name="aljaz_alg_12Feb" /> All opposition rallies were banned by the government, though at least 2,000 protesters forced their way through the security cordon around the Square to join other demonstrators.<ref name="aljaz12feb"/> Though minor protests occurred earlier in the day, most protesters came out after noon;<ref name="aljaz12febblog"/> several thousand protestors<ref name="nyt_alg_12Feb" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/news/algerian-police-clamp-down-on-pro-democracy-protest-news-international-lcmtufbbbeh.html |title=Algerian police clamp down on pro-democracy protest |publisher=sify news |date=12 February 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref> clashed with about 30,000 police at May First Square in central Algiers.<ref name="aljaz_alg_12Feb">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/201121235130627461.html |title=Algeria protesters push for change |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="nyt_alg_12Feb" /> Protesters chanted "''Djazair Horra Dimocratia''," ("A free and democratic Algeria") "''systÃ¨me dÃ©gage''" ("government out") and "Yesterday Egypt, today Algeria."<ref>{{cite news|author=|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/feb/12/algeria-egypt?CMP=twt_gu |title=Yesterday Egypt, today Algeria |publisher=Guardian |date=12 February 2011|accessdate=13 February 2011 |location=London |first=Karima |last=Bennoune}}</ref>
Police fired tear gas<ref name="aljazlive"/> on the protesters and arrested hundreds<ref name="aljaz_alg_12Feb" /> to possibly more than a 10,000 people,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/02/201121221035975455.html |title=Algeria's police crack down on protesters - Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref> including [[human rights in Algeria|human rights]] activists and [[trade union]] members.<ref>Al Jazeera (ref aljaz_alg_12Feb) writes "syndicate" members, presumably based on the French word "syndicat" for trade unions</ref> The Algerian League for the Defense of Human Rights said that up to 28,000 police officers were deployed in Algiers.<ref name="aljaz12feb"/> Many people, including a member of the [[People's National Assembly]], [[Boubkeur Derguini]]<ref name="assemblee_Boubkeur">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Derguini Boubkeur| work =| publisher =[[People's National Assembly]] | year=2011 | url =http://www.apn-dz.org/legislature_6/french/depute_detail_fr.php?mat=195 |format =| doi =| accessdate=12 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wS3LxjPk |archivedate=12 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name="Derguini_name_note">Family name Derguini [http://www.apn-dz.org/legislature_6/french/liste_fr_aprt_pol.php?mat_parti=6 according to Parliament], given name latin spelling "Boubkeur" according to same source.</ref> of the RCD, were injured.<ref name="algsoir_feb12_arrests">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =[[French language|french]] | title=Alger : La manifestation s'est dispersÃ©e | date=12 February 2011 | publisher=[[AlgÃ©rie Soir]] | url=http://www.algeriesoir.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=29973:&catid=36:algerie |accessdate=12 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wS2SpQpS |archivedate=12 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
Protesters had hoped to stay the night at the main square.<ref>{{cite web|first=Scott |last=Lucas |url=http://www.enduringamerica.com/home/2011/2/12/egypt-and-beyond-liveblog-where-next.html |title=Egypt (and Beyond) LiveBlog: Where Next? |publisher=EA WorldView |date=13 June 2009 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref> At almost 19:30, ''[[Thomson Reuters]]'' reported hundreds of people were leaving the demonstrations after about three hours and that the police opened their cordon to let them pass. It also said that about 200 young men from a poor neighbourhood stayed on and that some of them threw objects at the police.<ref name="aljaz12febblog">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/12/live-blog-feb-12-eye-algeria |title=Live blog Feb 12 - Eye on Algeria |publisher=Al Jazeera Blogs |date=12 February 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="ThomsReut_Feb12">{{cite news | first=Christian | last=Lowe |coauthors= Lamine Chikhi | pages= | language =| title=Algeria police stifle Egypt-inspired protest | date=12 February 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2011/02/12/idINIndia-54845720110212 |accessdate=13 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wS9W5wUH |archivedate=12 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
Protests were also reported in [[Constantine, Algeria|Constantine]], [[Annaba]], and [[Oran]]. There were reports of internet services like Twitter, Facebook and the wider internet to have been disrupted or shut down,<ref name="aljazlive"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Ramdani |first=Nabila |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/algeria/8320772/Algeria-shuts-down-internet-and-Facebook-as-protest-mounts.html |title=Algeria shuts down internet and Facebook as protest mounts |publisher=Telegraph |date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011 |location=London}}</ref> however, ''[[Renesys]]'' denied this had taken place.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cowie |first=James |url=http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/02/watching-algeria.shtml |title=Watching Algeria - Renesys Blog |publisher=Renesys.com |date=22 February 1999 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
[[SaÃ¯d Sadi]] of the [[Rally for Culture and Democracy|RCD]] interpreted the large number of police as government weakness, stating, "When you mobilize 30,000 police in the capital, that's a sign of weakness, not strength."<ref name="nyt_alg_12Feb" /> He also said that police charged at protesters and arrested 10 people outside the party offices as they celebrated Mubarak's resignation.<ref name="aljaz12feb"/> He added that 90-year-old human rights activist Ali Yahia Abdelnour was "manhandled by the police" and that the protesters were not "an organised demonstration. It was spontaneous. It was an explosion of joy."<ref name="aljaz12febblog"/>
===13â18 February=== On 13 February, following a suggestion by [[Ali Yahia Abdennour]] of the LADDH,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/feb/17/algeria-middleeast |title=Hopes and fears: an Algiers diary|author=Karima Bennoune |publisher=The Guardian |date=17 February 2011 |accessdate=17 February 2011 |location=London}}</ref> the CNCD<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lepoint.fr/monde/algerie-l-opposition-cncd-annonce-une-marche-le-19-fevrier-a-alger-13-02-2011-1294952_24.php |title=AlgÃ©rie: l'opposition CNCD annonce une marche le 19 fÃ©vrier Ã Alger |publisher=Le Point |date=13 February 2011 |accessdate=17 February 2011}}</ref> called for protests to continue every Saturday in the same square in Algiers, a call confirmed by RCD spokesman Mohsen Belabbes; Ali Yahia Abdennour said that "we will gather momentum as we progress we want our dignity back, yesterday the police has brutally beaten many protesters amongst them a pregnant women, old ladies, a journalist, young men and women, we should carry on protesting until we get our rights." The next day the activist blogger Hchicha called for alternative marches on Friday as well, meant to attract people wanting a change of system but distrusting the political parties involved in the CNCD.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O-eCgxlv_F0&feature=player_embedded |title=VENDREDI 18 FÃ©vrier - JOUR DE LA REVOLUTION EN ALGERIE |publisher=YouTube |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=17 February 2011}}</ref> Elias Filali reported that police had used tear gas to disperse protesters and to evict families who had occupied newly constructed homes overnight in Algiers.<ref name="aljazblog13feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/africa/2011/02/12/live-blog-feb-13-eye-algeria |title=Live blog Feb 13 - Eye on Algeria |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=|accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
On 14 February, Foreign Minister [[Mourad Medelci]] said the state of emergency would be lifted "within days."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/20112148175219570.html |title=Algeria 'to lift emergency laws' - Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Algeria-lifts-emergency-rule-as-protests-rage/articleshow/7496089.cms Algeria lifts emergency rule as protests rage] The Times of India, Februari 14 2011</ref> Two days later, Prime Minister [[Ahmed Ouyahia]] announced the state of emergency would be lifted by the end of February.<ref>{{cite news|last=Arnold |first=Chloe |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12490088 |title=Algerian founding father urges reform |publisher=BBC News |date=17 February 2011 |accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref>
Former FLN leader [[Abdelhamid Mehri]] called for true democracy, saying the current regime was incapable of solving the country's problems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i5W7ytS1WzWfDYrTdV5Reph7K99A?docId=CNG.68e525354daffd868eac000986513f10.871 |title=Top former Algerian leader calls for political change |publisher=AFP |date=17 February 2011 |accessdate=17 February 2011}}</ref>
On 18 February, a date for which a ''Facebook'' group had called for protests, police with water cannons were deployed in the main crossroads of Algiers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://elwatan.com/actualite/algerie-deploiement-important-de-la-police-a-alger-18-02-2011-112343_109.php |title=AlgÃ©rie : DÃ©ploiement important de la police Ã alger |publisher=El Watan |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011}}</ref>{{clarify|and...? were there protests?|date=February 2011}}
===19 February=== Thousands turned out in Algiers for protests but were unable to take control of the main square as of yet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/africa/2011/02/15/live-blog-eye-algeria |title=Live blog - Eye on Algeria |publisher=Al Jazeera Blogs |date=15 February 2011 |accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref>
===22 February=== The government officially announces the end of the emergency rule. The countryâs council of ministers adopted a law revoking the 1993 decree that prolonged a state of emergency originally instituted the previous year, stating that the âlaw will come into effect as soon as its imminent publication in the official journalâ.<ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-22/algeria-government-approves-lifting-of-state-of-emergency-1-.html Algeria Government Approves Lifting of State of Emergency] Bloomberg, February 22, 2011</ref>
===24 February=== The state of emergency in the country was officially lifted after being published in the country's [[official journal]], responding to one of the main demands of the protesters.<ref name="wp"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110224-718691.html |title=UPDATE: Algeria Ends 19-Year State Of Emergency |accessdate=26 February 2011 |date=24 February 2011 |publisher=The Wall Street Journal}} {{Dead link|date=June 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Algeria's state of emergency to be lifted 'imminently |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12546346 |accessdate=26 February 2011 |date=22 February 2011 |publisher=BBC}}</ref> The move legalizes protests outside the capital of Algiers, as long as the government is notified of planned demonstrations at least three days in advance.<ref name="wp"/> According to the country's interior minister, [[Dahou Ould Kabila]], protests are still banned within Algiers because of security concerns; he said that "Algiers is targeted by leaders of terrorist groups [because] it gives them media impact.<ref name="wp">{{cite news | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/24/AR2011022404846.html | title=Algeria's state of emergency is officially lifted | accessdate=25 February 2011 | date=24 February 2011 | publisher=The Washington Post | archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wluU0iPt | archivedate=25 February 2011}}</ref> The [[Algerian League for the Defense of Human Rights]], a leader of the protests, said it was a "ruse aimed at fooling international opinion at a time when Arab regimes are under pressure."<ref name="wp"/>
===2 March=== Protests continue throughout Algiers, although it is reported that the government has been keeping the country stable, although this momentary peace is expected to end soon.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/02/AR2011030202414.html | title=Algeria keeps lid on social unrest _ for now | work=The Washington Post}} {{Dead link|date=April 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
===5 March=== On 5 March, protests organised by the [[National Co-ordination for Democracy and Change]] in Algiers were violently suppressed while in al-Madania neighbourhood of [[Algiers]], a group of youths, wearing banners supporting Abdelaziz Bouteflika, tried to lynch opposition leader [[Said Sadi]], the president of the [[Rally for Culture and Democracy]]. Meanwhile, Algeria's oldest opposition party, [[Socialist Forces Front]], has urged Algerians to engage in a "peaceful struggle" for change in the nation.<ref>{{cite news |title=Youths 'attack Algerian protesters' |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/03/20113512417540287.html |newspaper= |date=5 March 2011 |accessdate=5 March 2011}}</ref>
===7 March=== Thousands of community police rallied in the capital Algiers despite a protest ban in the city, accusing the government of ingratitude, and insisting thousands of their colleagues have been killed or injured fighting Islamist violence. Demanding better pay and pensions, they got all the way to the Parliament building.<ref>[http://www.euronews.net/2011/03/07/police-protest-in-algerian-capital/ Police protest in Algerian capital | euronews, world news<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===16 March=== In Algiers, small group of around 150 or so threw [[Molotov cocktails]] at much larger crowd of police.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFLDE72F1VJ20110316 | work=Reuters | title=UPDATE 1-Algeria police use tear gas on protest in capital | date=16 March 2011}}</ref>
===23 March=== Police in the Algiers suburb of Oued Koriche used tear gas on Wednesday to disperse a crowd of young men who threw stones and [[Molotov Cocktails]] trying to stop bulldozers from demolishing dozens of illegally built homes. Five police officers were injured in the rioting, during which rioters threw bricks down on police from nearby rooftop and set fire to a car.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://af.reuters.com/article/algeriaNews/idAFLDE72M1W620110323 | work=Reuters | title=Algerian police clash with rioters in housing row | date=23 March 2011}}</ref>
===15 April=== In a long-awaited televised address, President Abdelaziz Bouteflika said he would seek constitutional amendments that would "reinforce representative democracy" and be submitted to parliament or to a referendum. He also proposed changes to laws on elections, the media or political parties.<ref>{{cite news |title=Algeria Leader Vows to 'Reinforce' Democracy |author=Benoit Faucon |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703327404576194363244985344.html?mod=googlenews_wsj |newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=15 April 2011 |accessdate=16 April 2011}}</ref>
===11 May=== 1,500 Doctors attempted to march towards government buildings but were prevented by anti-riot police. <ref>http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20110511/wl_africa_afp/algeriapoliticsunrestdemo_20110511154558</ref>
==Local protests over jobs and infrastructure== ===Late January 2011=== [[File:Marchedignite.jpg|thumb|200px|Students marching to [[el-Mouradia]]]]
The opposition group [[Rachad]] uploaded film of a non-violent demonstration of "more than 1000 people" demanding housing in the Said Hamdine neighbourhood of Algiers on 20 January, not widely reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rachad.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=617&catid=69&Itemid=101 |title=Plus de 1000 personnes organisent une marche de protestation Ã Alger le 20 janvier 2011 |publisher=Rachad |date=20 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
On 24 January, more than 500 people demonstrated in front of the ''daira'' building of [[Khemis El Khechna]], demanding water and gas connection and better housing for their nearby hometowns, [[Chebacheb]] and [[El Kerma]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tsa-algerie.com/divers/rassemblement-de-protestation-devant-la-wilaya-de-boumerdes_13920.html |title=TSA AlgÃ©rie, 24/01/2011, ''Rassemblement de protestation devant la wilaya de Boumerdes'' |publisher=Tsa-algerie.com |date=24 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> In [[Tizi Ouzou]] the same day, parents of youths detained in the protests of early January staged a sit-in in front of the [[wilaya]] seat building, demanding the release of their children,<ref>[http://www.elwatan.com/une/tizi-ouzou-sit-in-des-parents-des-detenus-des-dernieres-emeutes-devant-le-tribunal-24-01-2011-108631_108.php El Watan, 24/01/2011, ''Tizi Ouzou : Sit-in des parents des dÃ©tenus des derniÃ¨res Ã©meutes devant le tribunal'']{{dead link|date=February 2011}}</ref> who were provisionally released the next day.<ref>[http://www.elwatan.com/une/tizi-ouzou-les-douze-emeutiers-liberes-aujourd-hui-25-01-2011-108768_108.php ''Tizi Ouzou : Les douze Ã©meutiers libÃ©rÃ©s aujourdâhui'']{{dead link|date=February 2011}} El Watan, 25/01/2011</ref>
On 25 January, the inhabitants of El Djezzar in [[Batna Province|Batna]] occupied their [[town hall]], demanding a better [[road]] to their village.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elwatan.com/regions/est/batna/nouvelles-de-batna-25-01-2011-108675_132.php |title=El Watan, 25/01/2011, ''Des habitants occupent le siÃ¨ge de lâAPC dâ El Djezzar'' |publisher=Elwatan.com |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> On the same day, about a hundred inhabitants of Boutaleb near [[Chekfa]] blocked the main road, demanding gas and sewage connection for their town and better side roads.<ref>[http://www.elwatan.com/regions/est/jijel/la-route-de-boutaleb-bloquee-par-les-habitants-25-01-2011-108670_130.php ''La route de Boutaleb bloquÃ©e par les habitants''] El Watan, 25/01/2011</ref>
On 27 January, hundreds of inhabitants of Choukrane near [[Bouira]] closed the nearby national road (RN 29), demanding gas, water, a sewage system, and public lighting, as well as speed bumps to reduce traffic fatalities.<ref>[http://www.elwatan.com/une/bouira-des-citoyens-protestent-et-ferment-la-rn-26-27-01-2011-109083_108.php Bouira : des citoyens protestent et ferment la RN 26]{{dead link|date=February 2011}}, El Watan, 27/01/2011]</ref> On the same day, dozens of unemployed youths blocked RN 12 in [[Naciria]] near [[Boumerdes]] using burning tyres and other objects, demanding jobs.<ref>[http://www.elwatan.com/une/boumerdes-des-jeunes-chomeurs-en-colere-bloquent-la-rn-12-a-naciria-27-01-2011-109079_108.php BoumerdÃ¨s : des jeunes chÃ´meurs en colÃ¨re bloquent la RN 12 Ã Naciria, ''El Watan'', 27/01/2011]{{dead link|date=February 2011}}</ref>
On 30 January, unemployed youths closed the APC seat of [[Belaas]] in [[Ain Defla]], demanding jobs (according to the mayor), as well as better water and road management.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/une/ain-defla-le-siege-de-l-apc-de-belaas-ferme-par-de-jeunes-chomeurs-30-01-2011-109475_108.php | title= Ain Defla: Le siÃ¨ge de lâapc de Belaas fermÃ© par de jeunes chÃ´meursi | last= L. | first= Aziza | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=30 January 2011 | accessdate=30/01/2011 }}{{dead link|date=February 2011}}</ref> On the same day, 600 factory workers demonstrated in front of the wilaya seat in [[Bouira]], demanding to be re-hired by ENAD.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/des-travailleurs-de-l-enad-protestent-devant-la-wilaya-de-bouira-30-01-2011-109472_109.php | title= Des travailleurs de lâENAD protestent devant la wilaya de Bouira | last= Fedjkhi | first= Amar | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=30 January 2011 }}</ref> Also on the same day, unemployed youths in the wilaya of [[Ouargla Province|Ouargla]] demonstrated in [[Touggourt]] against the head of the local employment bureau, accused of favouritism.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/touggourt-nouvelle-manifestation-des-chomeurs-30-01-2011-109466_109.php | title= Touggourt : Nouvelle manifestation des chÃ´meurs | last= Alioua | first= Houria | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=30 January 2011 | accessdate=30/01/2011 }}</ref>
===February 2011===
On 1 February, the people of Raffour in [[M'chedallah]] near [[Bouira]] blocked national route 26 with burning tyres, demanding public lighting, a sewage system, and town planning. <ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/bouira-les-habitants-de-raffour-ferment-la-rn26-01-02-2011-109775_109.php | title= Bouira: Les habitants de Raffour ferment la RN26 | last= Fedjkhi | first= Amar | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=1 February 2011 | accessdate=01/02/2011 }}</ref> On the same day, the population of Tazgait in [[Mostaghanem]] closed their town hall, demanding that the mayor leave office for failing to do enough about the region's underdevelopment. <ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/mostaganem-la-population-de-tazgait-ferme-la-mairie-01-02-2011-109772_109.php | title= Mostaganem : La population de TazgaÃ¯t ferme la mairie | last= Yacine | first= A. | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=1 February 2011 | accessdate=01/02/2011 }}</ref>
On 7 February, youths at Toumiate in [[El Harrouch]] near [[Skikda]] blocked the national highway RN 3, and were attacked by riot police using tear gas.<ref name="AlgÃ©rie Focus">{{cite web | url= http://www.algerie-focus.com/2011/02/08/les-emeutes-reprennent-en-algerie-naciria-el-harrouch-sidi-amar-boumerdes/ | title= Les Ã©meutes reprennent en AlgÃ©rie : Naciria, El harrouch, Sidi Amar, Boumerdes.. | last= | first= | publisher= ''AlgÃ©rie Focus'' | date=8 February 2011 | accessdate=17/02/2011 }}</ref> On 8 February, youths in [[Sidi Amar]] near [[Annaba]] demonstrated to demand jobs, blocking the road and burning tyres.<ref name="AlgÃ©rie Focus"/>
From 6 to 9 February, protesters closed the national highway RN 26 at [[El Kseur]] near [[Bejaia]], demanding their jobs back or better compensation after the EPBTP milk factory where they were employed made them redundant. <ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.algeriesoir.com/general/090211-algerie-greves-marches-et-sit-in.html | title= AlgÃ©rie : GrÃ¨ves, marches et sit-in | last= Tarek | first= B. S. | publisher= ''AlgÃ©rie Soir'' | date=9 February 2011 | accessdate=17/02/2011 }}</ref>
On 8 and 9 February, youths in [[Naciria]] and [[Bordj-Menaiel]] attacked ANEM offices, confronted police, and closed the national highway RN 12, protesting unemployment and unfulfilled government promises of jobs. <ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.biladi.fr/021169353-algeriedes-chomeurs-en-colere-vague-de-protestations-bordj-menaiel-et-naciria | title= AlgÃ©rie/Des chÃ´meurs en colÃ¨re: Vague de protestations Ã Bordj MenaÃ¯el et Naciria | last= | first= | publisher= ''Le Midi Libre'' | date=10 February 2011 | accessdate=17/02/2011 }}</ref>
On 13 February, a crowd of youths gathered in front of the [[Annaba]] wilaya office demanding the 7000 jobs they had previously been promised, and greeted the governor with stone-throwing when he came out. One attempted to commit suicide, but was dissuaded by his brother.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.biladi.fr/021169553-algerie-annaba-le-wali-agresse-un-jeune-tente-de-se-suicider | title= AlgÃ©rie/Des chÃ´meurs en colÃ¨re: Vague de protestations Ã Bordj MenaÃ¯el et Naciria | last= Chams | first= Amar | publisher= ''Le Courrier d'AlgÃ©rie'' | date=13 February 2011 | accessdate=17/02/2011 }}</ref>
On 14 February, hundreds of youths protested over unemployment in [[Akbou]]; about 30 were hurt in clashes with the police.<ref>{{cite news | url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12460486 | title= Algeria unrest: Akbou protesters clash with police | publisher= ''BBC News'' | date=14 February 2011 | accessdate=20/02/2011 }}</ref>
On 16 February, youths in [[Tadmait]] ([[Tizi-Ouzou]]) went out on the streets demanding jobs, blocking the roads (including RN 12) with burning tires and damaging the APC office. Five of them were arrested after confrontations with anti-riot police.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/emeutes-a-tadmait-cinq-personnes-arretees-17-02-2011-112220_109.php | title= Ãmeutes Ã TadmaÃ¯t : Cinq personnes arrÃªtÃ©es | last= A. | first= Rachid | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=17 February 2011 | accessdate=17/02/2011 }}</ref>
Also on 16 February, about 80 unemployed youths occupied the daira offices in [[Hassi-Messaoud]] in protest against poverty and "hogra" (oppression) in the region that provides most of the country's oil income,<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/les-chomeurs-de-hassi-messaoud-menacent-de-recourir-a-l-emeute-17-02-2011-112210_109.php | title= Les chÃ´meurs de Hassi Messaoud menacent de recourir Ã l'Ã©meute | last= Semmar | first= Abderrahmane | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=17 February 2011 | accessdate=17/02/2011 }}</ref> and were dislodged by promises of jobs next week after hundreds of police and gendarmes gathered. On 17 February, about 500 youths demonstrated in front of the same daira office.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/tres-vive-tension-a-hassi-messaoud-500-jeunes-chomeurs-se-rassemblent-devant-la-daira-17-02-2011-112222_109.php | title= TrÃ¨s vive tension Ã Hassi Messaoud : 500 jeunes chÃ´meurs se rassemblent devant la daÃ¯ra | last= Semmar | first= Abderrahmane | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=17 February 2011 | accessdate=17/02/2011 }}</ref> Another 100 unemployed youths demonstrated in nearby [[Touggourt]], in front of the local office of the National Employment Agency.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/algerie-une-centaine-de-jeunes-chomeurs-manifestant-a-touggourt-17-02-2011-112226_109.php | title= AlgÃ©rie : Une centaine de jeunes chÃ´meurs manifestant Ã Touggourt | last= Semmar | first= Abderrahmane | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=17 February 2011 | accessdate=17/02/2011 }}</ref>
On 17 February, the [[Annaba]] wilaya offices were again targeted by demonstrators demanding jobs.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/les-demandeurs-d-emploi-reviennent-a-la-charge-17-02-2011-112151_109.php | title= Les demandeurs dâemploi reviennent Ã la charge | last= Gaidi | first= Mohamed Faouzi | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=17 February 2011 | accessdate=17/02/2011 }}</ref>
On 21 February, hundreds of students protesting in front of the Ministry of Higher Education against the new LMD system were dispersed forcibly by police.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/alger-la-police-reprime-des-etudiants-devant-le-siege-du-ministere-de-l-enseignement-superieur-21-02-2011-112816_109.php | title= Alger : La police rÃ©prime des Ã©tudiants devant le siÃ¨ge du ministÃ¨re de l'Enseignement SupÃ©rieur | last= Semmar | first= Abderrahmane | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=21 February 2011 | accessdate=21/02/2011 }}</ref> In [[Ammal]] ([[Boumerdes]]), demonstrators closed the local APC offices, demanding better housing.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/boumerdes-les-habitants-de-ammal-ferment-le-siege-de-l-apc-21-02-2011-112855_109.php | title= BoumerdÃ¨s : Les habitants de Ammal ferment le siÃ¨ge de lâAPC | last= Omar | first= Yacine | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=21 February 2011 | accessdate=21/02/2011 }}</ref>
On 23 February, villagers from nearby Imaghzarene closed the daira offices of [[Draa El Mizan]], demanding paving, public lighting, gas, more housing, and a clinic for their town.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/draa-el-mizan-tizi-ouzou-des-villageois-ferment-le-siege-de-la-daira-23-02-2011-113211_109.php | title= DraÃ¢ El Mizan (Tizi-Ouzou) : Des villageois ferment le siÃ¨ge de la daÃ¯ra | last= Essaid | first= Mouas | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=23 February 2011 | accessdate=23/02/2011 }}</ref> At [[Ammi Moussa]] ([[Relizane]]) dozens of youths gathered to blockade the town hall, demanding that the president and secretary-general of the APC resign. <ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/regions/centre/actu-ouest/relizane-la-population-de-ammi-moussa-assiege-la-mairie-23-02-2011-113070_222.php | title= Relizane : La population de Ammi Moussa assiÃ¨ge la mairie | last= B | first= Issac | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=23 February 2011 | accessdate=23/02/2011 }}</ref> On the same day, doctors in the [[Sidi Bel Abbes]] maternity ward staged a sit-in in protest against the lack of pharmaceutical supplies, which they said was preventing them from carrying out operations.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/sit-in-a-la-maternite-de-sidi-bel-abbes-23-02-2011-113207_109.php | title= Sit-in Ã la maternitÃ© de Sidi Bel AbbÃ¨s | last= B. | first= Abdelkrim | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=23 February 2011 | accessdate=23/02/2011 }}</ref> [[Bouzareah]] university students announced a strike demanding greater security at the university after a woman student was attacked by unknown assailants, who slashed her face, on campus grounds.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/universite-de-bouzareah-greve-generale-apres-l-agression-sauvage-d-une-etudiante-23-02-2011-113198_109.php | title= UniversitÃ© de BouzarÃ©ah: GrÃ¨ve gÃ©nÃ©rale aprÃ¨s l'agression sauvage d'une Ã©tudiante | last= Semmar | first= Abderrahmane | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=23 February 2011 | accessdate=23/02/2011 }}</ref>
On 24 February, unemployed youths gathered in front of the mayoralty of [[Sidi Lakhdar]] near [[Mostaganem]], after blocking the road (RN11) the previous day; they left when the mayor promised to review the housing lists.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/mostaganem-des-chomeurs-assiegent-la-mairie-de-sidi-lakhdar-24-02-2011-113377_109.php | title= Mostaganem : Des chÃ´meurs assiÃ¨gent la mairie de Sidi Lakhdar | last= Alim | first= Yacine | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=24 February 2011 | accessdate=24/02/2011 }}</ref> In [[Djelida]] ([[Ain Defla]]), the same day, about 500 people closed the APC offices, demanding jobs and protesting at the allocation of 117 new jobs to people from outside the region.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/djelida-ain-defla-des-centaines-de-citoyens-ferment-le-siege-de-l-apc-24-02-2011-113379_109.php | title= Djelida(Ain Defla) : Des centaines de citoyens ferment le siÃ¨ge de lâAPC | last= L. | first= Aziza | publisher= ''El Watan'' | date=24 February 2011 | accessdate=24/02/2011 }}</ref>
==Reactions== ;Domestic
In reaction to the protests of early January, starting 8 January the government decreased the prices of essential foods. Over following weeks it increased wheat supplies.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121210345525985.html |title=Middle East rulers make concessions |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=12 February 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
On 3 February Bouteflika announced plans to lift the emergency law, which prohibits protests without a permit, and substitute for it new anti-terrorism laws,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lexpress.fr/actualites/2/monde/l-etat-d-urgence-bientot-leve-en-algerie-dit-bouteflika_958630.html |title=L'Ã©tat d'urgence bientÃ´t levÃ© en AlgÃ©rie, dit Bouteflika |publisher=L'Express |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=17 February 2011}}</ref> but said that protests would remain illegal in Algiers in any case "for well-known reasons of public order".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://carnegieendowment.org/arb/?fa=show&article=42563 |title=Algerian president lifts the emergency law, except in Algiers |work=Arab Reform Bulletin |publisher=Carnegie Endowment for International Peace |date=9 February 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref> He also announced new measures to create jobs and that state-run television and radio should be open to all political parties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8084674-algeria-president-announced-the-lifting-of-emergency-laws |title=Algeria: President announced the lifting of emergency laws |publisher=Allvoices.com |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref> On 14 February, his foreign minister [[Mourad Medelci]] repeated the promise to end the state of emergency law, saying it would happen by the end of the month.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/africa/Algerian-Emergency-Law-said-to-be-Ending-116151639.html |title=Algerian Emergency Law to End |publisher=Allvoices.com |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=17 February 2011}}</ref> on 22 February the cabinet voted to lift the emergency law. It also voted on a measure to alleviate unemployment.<ref>Al Jazeera. Headlines.</ref>
In efforts to discourage the protests organised by the CNCD, the authorities played up the role of the RCD, a mainly Kabyle party unpopular elsewhere in the country, within them; while this tactic had some success, it did not stop demonstrators from turning out in some non-Kabyle cities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.north-africa.com/naj_news/news_na/1northafricaunderstress46.html |title=North Africa Under Stress: Latest Developments |publisher=The North Africa Journal |date=10 February 2011 |accessdate=17 February 2011}}</ref>
;International * {{flag|European Union}} - [[President of the European Parliament|President]] of the [[European Parliament]] [[Jerzy Buzek]] said that he "call[ed] upon the Algerian authorities to refrain from violence and respect their citizens' right to peaceful demonstration. Any and all demonstrators arrested should be released immediately. The continuing state of emergency is unjustifiable and clearly hampers Algeria's prospects for the fair, peaceful and sustainable development of the country. It is but a first step in responding to the legitimate democratic aspirations of the Algerian people, but even this step has yet to materialise. Opposition groups, civil society, and especially young people should have the right to freely express their criticism of the government. No government can ignore the call of its people."
* {{flag|France}} Foreign Ministry spokesman Bernard Valero said regarding the demonstrations that "What is important in our eyes us is that freedom of expression is respected and that the demonstrations are able to take place freely and without violence", and welcomed the planned end to the State of Emergency.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jXrIiCJAAReaAnMIeheQpttKVh-Q?docId=CNG.158cf120b22d1fab72b87226699036ea.6b1 |title=France asks Algeria to allow peaceful protests |publisher=AFP |date=14 February 2010 |accessdate=17 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|Germany}} - Foreign Minister [[Guido Westerwelle]] said Germany was "on the side of democrats. The German government calls on the Algerian government to renounce all recourse to violence. These are demonstrators who want freedom, who are doing nothing more than exercising a human right, to know the right to defend with dignity their point of view. As democrats we are on the side of democrats. I have already said that about Tunisia and Egypt. I say it again now in allusion to other countries."<ref>{{cite web|author=Leigh Phillips |url=http://euobserver.com/9/31801 |title=EUobserver / EU Parliament chief condemns Algeria crackdown |publisher=Euobserver.com |date=|accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|United States}} - [[Department of State]] spokesman PJ Crowley said that "We note the ongoing protests in Algeria, and call for restraint on the part of the security services. In addition, we reaffirm our support for the universal rights of the Algerian people, including assembly and expression. These rights apply on the internet. Moreover, these rights must be respected. We will continue to follow the situation closely in the days ahead."<ref name="aljazblog13feb"/>
;Other Regional financial stock market indices fell on 20 February on concern of spreading instability.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hankir |first=Zahra |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-20/dubai-shares-drop-most-this-month-on-growing-mideast-unrest-emaar-falls.html |title=Dubai Shares Drop as Mideast Unrest Sparks Risk Aversion; Emaar, Zain Fall |publisher=Bloomberg |date=20 February 2011 |accessdate=26 February 2011}}</ref>
;NGOs * The [[Al-Qaeda Organization in the Islamic Maghreb]] voiced support for the demonstrators against both the Tunisian and Algerian governments in a video released on 13 January 2011. AQIM leader [[Abu Musab Abdul Wadud]] offered military aid and training to the demonstrators.<ref>{{cite news|title=Al-Qaeda supports the events in Tunisia and Algeria |author=ennahar|url=http://www.ennaharonline.com/en/news/5541.html|newspaper=Ennaharonline/ M. O.|date=14 January 2011|accessdate=15 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=AQIM leader exploits Tunisia, Algeria unrest |author=Adem Amine in Algiers and Jamel Arfaoui in Tunis for Magharebia|url=http://www.magharebia.com/cocoon/awi/xhtml1/en_GB/features/awi/features/2011/01/13/feature-01|newspaper=Magharebia|date=13 January 2011|accessdate=15 January 2011}}</ref>
* [[Amnesty International]] issued a statement that read: "Algerians must be allowed to express themselves freely and hold peaceful protests in Algiers and elsewhere. We urge the Algerian authorities not to respond to these demands by using excessive force."<ref name="aljaz12feb">{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/201121235130627461.html |title=Algeria protesters push for change |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=12 February 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
* On 21 January, the international group [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] declared a cyber-war on the Algerian state on the grounds of censorship, following previous efforts in Tunisia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://anonnews.org/?p=press&a=item&i=268 |title=AnonNews, 21/01/2011, ''Operation Algeria'' |publisher=Anonnews.org |date=21 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> The next day they brought down the pro-government [[National Rally for Democracy (Algeria)|RND]] party website, having previously brought down the sites of the Ministry of the Interior and the [[Entreprise nationale de tÃ©lÃ©vision|national TV station]].<ref>{{cite web|author=le devoir de savoir ALGERIE-FOCUS |url=http://algerie-focus.com/2011/01/22/derniere-minute-le-site-du-rnd-mis-hors-service-par-the-anonymous/ |title=AlgÃ©rie Focus, 22/01/2011, DerniÃ¨re minute. Le site du RND mis hors service par The Anonymous |publisher=Algerie-focus.com |date=22 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
